A method to update any {@link ApplicationLayout} values

methods.javadoc:
Determine if test failure occur (for use within tear down methods)
@return true if test failure detected

methods.comment: Determine if test failure occur (for use within tear down methods)

return.comment: true if test failure detected

methods.name: testFailed
methods.comment:
A callback for subclasses when a test has failed. This will be called
 before tearDown()

params.name: e
params.comment: the exception that happened when the test failed

methods.javadoc:
Returns the window parent of c. If c is a window, then c is returned.

Warning: this differs from {@link SwingUtilities#windowForComponent(Component)} in that the latter method will not return the given component if it is a window. @param c the component @return the window
methods.name: windowForComponent
methods.comment:
Returns the window parent of c. If c is a window, then c is returned.

 
 Warning: this differs from
 SwingUtilities#windowForComponent(Component) in that the latter
 method will not return the given component if it is a window.

params.name: c
params.comment: the component

return.comment: the window

methods.javadoc:
Gets all windows in the system (including Frames).
@return all windows

methods.comment: Gets all windows in the system (including Frames).

return.comment: all windows

methods.name: loadTextResource

Load a text resource file into an ArrayList. Each line of the file is
 stored as an item in the list.

params.comment: class where resource exists

params.name: name
params.comment: resource filename

return.comment: list of lines contained in file

methods.name: getTestDataFile
methods.comment:
Returns the file within the data directory of the TestResources module
 that matches the given relative path
 
 A FileNotFoundException is throw if the file does not exist.

path relative to the data directory of the TestResources
            module.

throws.comment: if the given file does not exist

return.comment:
the file within the data directory of the TestResources module
         that matches the given relative path

methods.name: getTestDataDir

Returns a file that points to the location on disk of the given relative
 path name. The path is relative to the test resources directory.

throws.comment: If the directory does not exist
if the given path does not represent a directory

return.comment: a file that points to the location on disk of the relative path.

methods.javadoc:

Null is returned if the file could not be found. @param path path relative to the data directory of the TestResources module. @return the file within the data directory of the TestResources module that matches the given relative path

 Null is returned if the file could not be found.

path relative to the data directory of the TestResources
            module.

the file within the data directory of the TestResources module

methods.javadoc:
Waits for all system tasks to complete. These tasks are tracked by the
 SystemUtilities during testing only.
@throws AssertionFailedError if the timeout period expires while waiting
             for tasks
methods.name: waitForTasks
methods.comment:
Waits for all system tasks to complete. These tasks are tracked by the
 SystemUtilities during testing only.

methods.name: getInstanceFieldByClassType
methods.comment:
Get the first field object contained within object ownerInstance which
 has the type classType. This method is only really useful if it is known
 that only a single field of classType exists within the ownerInstance.

return.comment: field object of type classType or null

methods.name: setInstanceField
methods.comment:
Sets the instance field by the given name on the given object instance.
 
 Note: if the field is static, then the ownerInstance field can
 be the class of the object that contains the variable.

params.name: fieldName
params.comment: The name of the field to retrieve.

params.name: ownerInstance
params.comment:
The object instance from which to get the variable
            instance.

params.name: value
params.comment: The value to use when setting the given field

throws.comment:
if there is a problem accessing the field using
             reflection. A RuntimeException is used so that calling tests
             can avoid using a try/catch block, but will still fail when
             an error is encountered.

methods.name: getInstanceField
methods.comment:
Gets the instance field by the given name on the given object instance.
 The value is a primitive wrapper if it is a primitive type.
 
 Note: if the field is static, then the ownerInstance field can
 be the class of the object that contains the variable.

params.name: fieldName
params.comment: The name of the field to retrieve.

params.name: ownerInstance
params.comment:
The object instance from which to get the variable
            instance.

throws.comment:
if there is a problem accessing the field using
             reflection. A RuntimeException is used so that calling tests
             can avoid using a try/catch block, but will still fail when
             an error is encountered.

return.comment: The field instance.

methods.name: invokeConstructor
methods.comment:
Uses reflection to execute the constructor for the given class with the
 given parameters. The new instance of the given class will be returned.

params.name: containingClass
params.comment: The class that contains the desired constructor.

params.name: parameterTypes
params.comment:
The parameter types that the constructor
            takes. This value can be null or zero length if there are no
            parameters to pass

params.name: args
params.comment:
The parameter values that should be passed to the
            constructor. This value can be null or zero length if there
            are no parameters to pass

throws.comment:
if there is a problem accessing the constructor
             using reflection. A RuntimeException is used so that calling
             tests can avoid using a try/catch block, but will still fail
             when an error is encountered.

return.comment: The new class instance

methods.name: invokeInstanceMethod
methods.comment:
Uses reflection to execute the method denoted by the given method name.
 If any value is returned from the method execution, then it will be
 returned from this method. Otherwise, null is returned.
 
 Note: if the method is static, then the ownerInstance field can
 be the class of the object that contains the method.

params.name: methodName
params.comment: The name of the method to execute.

params.name: ownerInstance
params.comment:
The object instance of which the method will be
            executed.

params.name: parameterTypes
params.comment: The parameter types that the method takes.

params.name: args
params.comment:
The parameter values that should be passed to the method.
            This value can be null or zero length if there are no
            parameters to pass

throws.comment:
if there is a problem accessing the field using
             reflection. A RuntimeException is used so that calling tests
             can avoid using a try/catch block, but will still fail when
             an error is encountered.

return.comment: The return value as returned from executing the method.

methods.name: invokeInstanceMethod
methods.comment:
This method is just a "pass through" method for
 #invokeInstanceMethod(String, Object, Class[], Object[]) so that
 callers do not need to pass null to that method when the underlying
 instance method does not have any parameters.

params.name: methodName
params.comment: The name of the method to execute.

params.name: ownerInstance
params.comment:
The object instance of which the method will be
            executed.

throws.comment:
if there is a problem accessing the field using
             reflection. A RuntimeException is used so that calling tests
             can avoid using a try/catch block, but will still fail when
             an error is encountered.

return.comment: The return value as returned from executing the method.

methods.name: pressButtonByText

params.name: container
params.comment: the container to search. (Typically a dialog.)

params.name: buttonText
params.comment: the text on the desired JButton.

methods.name: pressButtonByText
methods.comment:
Finds the button with the indicated TEXT that is a sub-component of the
 indicated container, and then programmatically presses the button.

params.name: container
params.comment: the container to search. (Typically a dialog.)

params.name: buttonText
params.comment: the text on the desired JButton.

params.name: waitForCompletion
params.comment:
if true wait for action to complete before
            returning, otherwise schedule action to be performed and
            return immediately.

methods.name: pressButtonByName
methods.comment:
Finds the button with the indicated NAME that is a subcomponent of the
 indicated container, and then programmatically presses the button.

params.name: container
params.comment: the container to search. (Typically a dialog)

params.name: buttonName
params.comment:
the name on the desired AbstractButton (see
            Component.setName())

methods.name: pressButtonByName
methods.comment:
Finds the button with the indicated NAME that is a subcomponent of the
 indicated container, and then programmatically presses the button.

params.name: container
params.comment: the container to search. (Typically a dialog.)

params.name: buttonName
params.comment:
the name on the desired AbstractButton (see
            Component.setName()).

params.name: waitForCompletion
params.comment:
if true wait for action to complete before
            returning, otherwise schedule action to be performed and
            return immediately

Programmatically presses the indicated button.
@param button the button

methods.comment: Programmatically presses the indicated button.

params.comment: the button

methods.comment: Programmatically presses the indicated button.

if true wait for action to complete before
            returning, otherwise schedule action to be performed and

methods.name: findComponentByName
methods.comment:
Searches the subcomponents of the indicated container and returns the
 component with the specified name.

params.name: container
params.comment: the container to search

params.name: componentName
params.comment: the name of the desired component

return.comment: the component, or null if not found

methods.name: findButtonByText
methods.comment:
Searches the subcomponents of the the given container and returns the
 JButton that has the specified text.

params.name: container
params.comment: the container to search

params.name: text
params.comment: the button text

return.comment: the JButton, or null the button was not found

methods.javadoc:
Searches the sub-components of the given container and returns the AbstractButton that has the specified text.

This differs from {@link #findButtonByText(Container, String)} in that this method will find buttons that do not extend from {@link JButton}. That method is convenient when you do not wish to cast the result from AbstractButton to JButton. Other than that, this method can handle all cases the other method cannot. @param container container to search @param text button text @return null if the button was not found
methods.name: findAbstractButtonByText
methods.comment:
Searches the sub-components of the given container and returns the
 AbstractButton that has the specified text.
 
 This differs from #findButtonByText(Container, String) in that
 this method will find buttons that do not extend from JButton.
 That method is convenient when you do not wish to cast the result from
 AbstractButton to JButton. Other than that, this method can handle all
 cases the other method cannot.

params.name: container
params.comment: container to search

params.name: text
params.comment: button text

return.comment: null if the button was not found

methods.name: findAbstractButtonByName
methods.comment:
Searches the sub-components of the given container and returns the
 AbstractButton that has the specified name.

params.name: container
params.comment: container to search

params.name: name
params.comment: the button name (you must set this manually).

return.comment: null if the button was not found

methods.name: clickMouse
methods.comment: Simulates click the mouse button.

params.name: comp
params.comment: the component to click on.

params.name: button
params.comment: the mouse button (1, 2, or 3)

params.name: x
params.comment: the x coordinate of the click location

params.name: y
params.comment: the y coordinate of the click location

params.name: clickCount
params.comment: the number of clicks (2 = double click)

params.name: modifiers
params.comment: additional modifiers (e.g. MouseEvent.SHIFT_MASK)

params.name: popupTrigger
params.comment:
a boolean, true if this event is a trigger for a
            popup menu

methods.name: clickMouse
methods.comment: Simulates click the mouse button.

params.name: comp
params.comment: the component to click on.

params.name: button
params.comment: the mouse button (1, 2, or 3)

params.name: x
params.comment: the x coordinate of the click location

params.name: y
params.comment: the y coordinate of the click location

params.name: clickCount
params.comment: the number of clicks (2 = double click)

params.name: modifiers
params.comment: additional modifiers (e.g. MouseEvent.SHIFT_MASK)

params.name: y

methods.name: runSwing
methods.comment:
Returns the value from the given Supplier, invoking the call in
 the Swing thread. This is useful when you may have values that are being
 changed on the Swing thread and you need the test thread to see the
 changes.

params.name: s
params.comment: the supplier

return.comment: the value returned by the supplier

methods.name: runSwingWithExceptions
methods.comment:
Call this version of #runSwing(Runnable) when you expect your runnable to throw
 an exception

params.name: runnable
params.comment: the runnable

params.name: wait
params.comment: true signals to wait for the Swing operation to finish

throws.comment: any excption that is thrown on the Swing thread

methods.javadoc:
Launches the runnable on a new thread so as to not block the calling
 thread. This is very useful for performing actions on the Swing thread
 that show modal dialogs, which would otherwise block the calling thread,
 such as a testing thread.
@param runnable The runnable that will be executed in a new Thread that
            will place the runnable on the Swing thread.
methods.name: executeOnSwingWithoutBlocking
methods.comment:
Launches the runnable on a new thread so as to not block the calling
 thread. This is very useful for performing actions on the Swing thread
 that show modal dialogs, which would otherwise block the calling thread,
 such as a testing thread.

params.name: runnable
params.comment:
The runnable that will be executed in a new Thread that
            will place the runnable on the Swing thread.

methods.name: findTreePathToText
methods.comment:
Finds the path of a tree node in the indicated tree with the specified
 text. The matching tree node is determined by comparing the specified
 text with the string returned by the tree node's toString() method. 
 Note: This method affects the expansion state of the tree. It will expand
 nodes starting at the root until a match is found or all of the tree is
 checked.

params.name: tree
params.comment: the tree

params.name: text
params.comment: the tree node's text

return.comment: the tree path

methods.name: findPathToText
methods.comment: Performs a depth first search for the named tree node.

params.name: tree
params.comment: the tree to search

params.name: startTreePath
params.comment:
path indicating node to begin searching from in the
            tree

params.name: text
params.comment: the name of the node to find

return.comment: the path to the named node or null if it can't be found.

methods.name: createStackTraceForAllThreads
methods.comment:
Returns a string which is a printout of a stack trace for each thread
 running in the current JVM

return.comment: the stack trace string

methods.name: toString
methods.comment:
Prints the contents of the given collection by way of the
 Object#toString() method.

params.name: collection
params.comment: The contents of which to print

return.comment: A string representation of the given collection

methods.javadoc: Invoke fixupGUI at the beginning of your JUnit test or in its setup() method to make your GUI for the JUnit test appear using the system Look & Feel. The system look and feel is the default that Ghidra uses. This will also change the default fonts for the JUnit test to be the same as those in Ghidra. @exception InterruptedException if we're interrupted while waiting for the event dispatching thread to finish excecuting doRun.run() @exception InvocationTargetException if an exception is thrown while running doRun
methods.name: fixupGUI
methods.comment:
Invoke fixupGUI at the beginning of your JUnit test or in
 its setup() method to make your GUI for the JUnit test appear using the
 system Look  Feel. The system look and feel is the default that Ghidra
 uses. This will also change the default fonts for the JUnit test to be
 the same as those in Ghidra.

methods.javadoc:
Waits for the Swing thread to process any pending events. This method
 also waits for any {@link SwingUpdateManager}s that have pending events
 to be flushed.
@return true if the any {@link SwingUpdateManager}s were busy.
methods.name: waitForSwing
methods.comment:
Waits for the Swing thread to process any pending events. This method
 also waits for any SwingUpdateManagers that have pending events
 to be flushed.

return.comment: true if the any SwingUpdateManagers were busy.

methods.javadoc:
This is only for internal use. If you need to wait for the Swing thread
 from your test, then use {@link #waitForSwing()}.
@deprecated This is not a test writer's method, but instead an
             infrastructure method.
methods.name: privateWaitForPostedSwingRunnables_SwingSafe
methods.comment:
This is only for internal use. If you need to wait for the Swing thread
 from your test, then use #waitForSwing().

methods.javadoc:
Returns the directory into which tests can write debug files, such as files containing print statements or image files.

This is not a temporary directory that will be deleted between tests, which is useful in that the debug files will persist after a test run.

Examples of this directory:

  • server: {share dir}/junits.new/JunitTest_version/reports
  • local gradle: {user home}/git/{repo}/ghidra/build/JUnit/reports
  • eclipse: {module}/bin/
@return the directory
methods.name: getDebugFileDirectory
methods.comment:
Returns the directory into which tests can write debug files, such as
 files containing print statements or image files.

 
 This is not a temporary directory that will be deleted between tests,
 which is useful in that the debug files will persist after a test run.

 
 Examples of this directory:
 
 server: {share dir}/junits.new/JunitTest_version/reports
 local gradle: {user home}/git/{repo}/ghidra/build/JUnit/reports
 eclipse: {module}/bin/

return.comment: the directory

methods.javadoc:
Creates a sub-directory with the given name as a child of the Java temp directory. The given name will be the prefix of the new directory name, with any additional text as created by {@link Files#createTempDirectory(Path, String, java.nio.file.attribute.FileAttribute...)}. Any left-over test directories will be cleaned-up before creating the new directory.

Note: you should not call this method multiple times, as each call will cleanup the previously created directories. @param name the name of the directory to create @return the newly created directory @throws IOException of there is a problem creating the new directory
methods.name: createTempDirectory
methods.comment:
Creates a sub-directory with the given name as a child of the Java
 temp directory. The given name will be the prefix of the new directory
 name, with any additional text as created by
 Files#createTempDirectory(Path, String, java.nio.file.attribute.FileAttribute...).
 Any left-over test directories will be cleaned-up before creating the new
 directory.
 
 
 Note: you should not call this method multiple times, as each call will
 cleanup the previously created directories.

params.name: name
params.comment: the name of the directory to create

throws.comment: of there is a problem creating the new directory

return.comment: the newly created directory

methods.name: createTempFilePath
methods.comment:
Creates a file path with a filename that is under the system temp
 directory. The path returned will not point to an existing file. The
 suffix of the file will be .tmp.

params.name: name
params.comment: the filename

throws.comment:
if there is any problem ensuring that the created
             path is non-existent

return.comment: a new file path

methods.name: createTempFilePath
methods.comment:
Creates a file path with a filename that is under the system temp
 directory. The path returned will not point to an existing file. This
 method is the same as #createTempFilePath(String), except that
 you must provide the extension.

params.name: name
params.comment: the filename

params.name: extension
params.comment: the file extension

throws.comment:
if there is any problem ensuring that the created
             path is non-existent

return.comment: a new file path

methods.name: createTempFileForTest
methods.comment:
Creates a temp file for the current test, using the test name as a prefix
 for the filename. This method calls #createTempFile(String),
 which will cleanup any pre-existing temp files whose name pattern matches
 this test name. This helps to avoid old temp files from accumulating.

throws.comment: if there is a problem creating the new file

return.comment: the new temp file

methods.name: createTempFileForTest
methods.comment:
Creates a temp file for the current test, using the test name as a prefix
 for the filename. This method calls #createTempFile(String),
 which will cleanup any pre-existing temp files whose name pattern matches
 this test name. This helps to avoid old temp files from accumulating.

params.name: suffix
params.comment: the suffix to provide for the temp file

throws.comment: if there is a problem creating the new file

return.comment: the new temp file

methods.name: createTempFile
methods.comment:
Creates a file in the Java temp directory using the given name as a
 prefix and the given suffix. The final filename will also include the
 current test name, as well as any data added by
 File#createTempFile(String, String). The file suffix will be
 .tmp
 
 The file will be marked to delete on JVM exit. This will not work if the
 JVM is taken down the hard way, as when pressing the stop button in
 Eclipse.

params.name: name
params.comment: the prefix to put on the file, before the test name

throws.comment: if there is a problem creating the new file

return.comment: the newly created file

methods.javadoc:
Creates a file in the Java temp directory using the given name as a prefix and the given suffix. The final filename will also include the current test name, as well as any data added by {@link File#createTempFile(String, String)}.

The file will be marked to delete on JVM exit. This will not work if the JVM is taken down the hard way, as when pressing the stop button in Eclipse.

Note: This method will create the file on disk! If you need the file to not exist, then you must delete the file yourself. Alternatively, you could instead call {@link #createTempFilePath(String, String)}, which will ensure that the created temp file is deleted.

Finally, this method will delete any files that match the given name and suffix values before creating the given temp file. This is important, as it will delete any files already created by the test that match this info. @param name the prefix to put on the file, before the test name @param suffix the file suffix @return the newly created file @throws IOException if there is a problem creating the new file @see #createTempFile(String)
methods.name: createTempFile
methods.comment:
Creates a file in the Java temp directory using the given name as a
 prefix and the given suffix. The final filename will also include the
 current test name, as well as any data added by
 File#createTempFile(String, String).
 
 The file will be marked to delete on JVM exit. This will not work if the
 JVM is taken down the hard way, as when pressing the stop button in
 Eclipse.
 
 Note: This method will create the file on disk! If you need the
 file to not exist, then you must delete the file yourself. Alternatively,
 you could instead call #createTempFilePath(String, String), which
 will ensure that the created temp file is deleted.

 
 Finally, this method will delete any files that match the given name and
 suffix values before creating the given temp file. This is important,
 as it will delete any files already created by the test that match this
 info.

params.name: name
params.comment: the prefix to put on the file, before the test name

params.name: suffix
params.comment: the file suffix

throws.comment: if there is a problem creating the new file

return.comment: the newly created file

methods.name: deleteSimilarTempFiles
methods.comment:
Delete any files under the Java temp directory that have the given text
 in their name.

params.name: nameText
params.comment: the partial name text to match against the files

methods.name: deleteMatchingTempFiles
methods.comment:
Delete any files under the this test case's specific temp directory that
 match the give regex Pattern

params.name: namePattern
params.comment: the pattern to match against the files

fields.javadoc: Property that defines the test report output directory
fields.name: GHIDRA_TEST_PROPERTY_REPORT_DIR
fields.comment: Property that defines the test report output directory
